name: Rajgad
historicalSignificance: The King of Forts - Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj's First Capital.

history.summary: Rajgad served as the first capital of the Maratha Empire under Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, renowned for its strategic design and historical importance.

detailed.title: Early History and Construction:
detailed.content: Rajgad was originally known as Murumbdev and was part of the Nizam Shahi dynasty's territory. The fort was under various rulers before being captured by Shivaji Maharaj around 1646-1647, during his early military campaigns. Once in Maratha hands, the fort was renamed Rajgad and became a key base for Shivaji Maharaj's expanding empire.

detailed.title: Capital of the Maratha Empire:
detailed.content: Shivaji Maharaj made Rajgad his capital in the early years of his reign. From 1647 to 1670, Rajgad was the center of administration and governance. The fort's strategic location provided a strong defensive position and control over the surrounding region.

detailed.title: Rajgad's Role in the Maratha Empire
detailed.content: Rajgad was not just a military base but also the administrative center for several key decisions that laid the foundation of the Maratha Empire’s expansion. Chhatrapati Sambhaji Maharaj's coronation here further emphasized its importance in Maratha history.

detailed.title: Invasion of Shahiste Khan (1660):
detailed.content: In 1660, under the command of Aurangzeb, Shahiste Khan attempted an invasion of Shivaji Maharaj's territories. According to Persian sources, Shahiste Khan sent forces towards Rajgad, who destroyed several nearby villages. However, they did not try to capture the fort itself. On April 6, 1663, Shivaji Maharaj launched a surprise attack on Shahiste Khan, and Rajgad was secured.

detailed.title: Mirza Raja Jai Singh's Campaign (1665):
detailed.content: In 1665, when Mirza Raja Jai Singh of the Mughal Empire launched an attack on Shivaji Maharaj's kingdom, he sent his generals, Dawood Khan and Ra Singh, to capture Rajgad. On April 30, 1665, the Mughal forces attempted to capture the fort, but they were repelled by the fierce resistance of the Marathas.

detailed.title: Birthplace of Rajaram Maharaj:
detailed.content: Rajgad is also notable for being the birthplace of Rajaram Maharaj, the younger son of Shivaji Maharaj. He was born here on February 24, 1670.

detailed.title: The Fall of Rajgad to the Mughals:
detailed.content: After the death of Shivaji Maharaj in 1680, Rajgad fell into the hands of the Mughals in 1689 under Aurangzeb's orders. However, it was quickly recaptured by the Marathas in 1707 under the leadership of Gunaji Sawant.

detailed.title: Later Use and Administration:
detailed.content: After the fall of Rajgad to the Mughals, it was reoccupied by the Marathas. During the Peshwa era, the fort's administration was handed over to various officers, including the Shilimkar and Pawar families. The fort continued to hold strategic importance, but its role as the capital was eventually replaced by Raigad Fort in 1670.

name: Raigad
historicalSignificance: The Crown of the Maratha Empire - Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj's Coronation Fort.

history.summary: Raigad Fort, known as the coronation site of Shivaji Maharaj, stands as a monumental symbol of the Maratha Empire.

detailed.title: Raigad - The Maratha Capital
detailed.content: Raigad was the capital of the Maratha Empire and the location where Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj was crowned in 1674. The fort was known for its massive fortifications and strategic location.

detailed.title: Ancient Names and Capture by Shivaji Maharaj
detailed.content: Originally known as Raayri, Raigad was referred to as the 'Eastern Gibraltar' by Europeans. Shivaji Maharaj captured the fort in 1656 after defeating the Mores of Javali, marking the beginning of its transformation into a formidable stronghold.

detailed.title: The Coronation of Shivaji Maharaj
detailed.content: Shivaji Maharaj’s coronation on 6th June 1674 at the Rajsabha of Raigad symbolized the formal establishment of the Maratha Empire. A second coronation ceremony, performed on 24th September 1674 by the Nischalpuri Gosavi, ensured spiritual legitimacy.

detailed.title: Personal Milestones and Shivaji Maharaj's Legacy
detailed.content: Raigad witnessed significant personal milestones, including the Munja ceremonies of Sambhaji Maharaj in 1675 and Rajaram Maharaj in 1680. It also bore witness to the death of Shivaji Maharaj on 3rd April 1680, a sorrowful moment marked by earthquakes and devastation.

detailed.title: The Siege and Fall of Raigad
detailed.content: After Shivaji Maharaj’s death, Rajaram Maharaj defended Raigad against Mughal attacks. In 1689, the fort fell to the Mughals due to betrayal by Suryaji Pisal and was renamed Islamgad. However, the Marathas recaptured it under Chhatrapati Shahu Maharaj in 1733.

detailed.title: Raigad's Reclamation and Restoration
detailed.content: In 1733, Raigad was reclaimed by the Marathas under Chhatrapati Shahu Maharaj. The fort was restored and continued to hold immense strategic and historical importance in the Maratha Empire.

detailed.title: Architectural Highlights of Raigad
detailed.content: Raigad is known for its grand architecture, including the Maha Darwaja, the largest gate, and Hirkani Buruj, a site linked to the legendary story of Hirkani, a mother who descended the cliffs to return to her child.

name: Sindhudurg
historicalSignificance: The Gateway to Maratha Naval Power - Built by Shivaji Maharaj in 1664.

history.summary: Sindhudurg Fort, located on an island, is a symbol of Maratha naval strength, built by Shivaji Maharaj to safeguard the western coast.

detailed.title: Foundation and Construction
detailed.content: On 25th November 1664, Shivaji Maharaj performed a sacred ritual, offering a golden coconut to the sea, before laying the foundation of Sindhudurg Fort. The construction took over 3 years and involved 500 stonecutters, 200 blacksmiths, and 3,000 laborers. The fort was completed on 29th March 1667 under Shivaji Maharaj’s supervision.

detailed.title: Strategic Naval Importance
detailed.content: Sindhudurg was built to protect the Konkan coast from maritime threats and was key in establishing the Maratha Navy. The fort's design, with molten lead poured into the foundation, ensured it was resilient to sea waves.

detailed.title: Role in the Maratha Empire
detailed.content: The fort's strategic location helped in maintaining control over the sea route and safeguarding the Maratha Empire’s coastline. It was one of the most important forts for the Marathas in their naval and coastal defense.

detailed.title: Shivaji Era
detailed.content: After Shivaji Maharaj's death in 1680, the fort changed hands. In 1765, the British captured Sindhudurg and renamed it Fort Augustus. It was returned to the Marathas in 1766 after an agreement between Queen Jijabai and the East India Company. In 1792, it was taken over by the British once again.

name: Shivneri
historicalSignificance: The Birthplace of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj - A Fort of Heritage and Valor.

history.summary: Shivneri Fort was the birthplace of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, known for its strategic significance in protecting the region.

detailed.title: Shivneri Fort: Birthplace of Shivaji Maharaj
detailed.content: Shahaji Raja, who was in the midst of the wars between the Mughals, Nizamshahi, and Adilshahi, chose Shivneri Fort in Junnar Maval to keep his pregnant wife Jijabai safe. The fort was safe due to the steep slopes on the hill of the fort, strong fortifications, strong towers, and the protection of the seven guards of the fort. Shahaji Raja sent Jijabai to Shivneri with 500 cavalry. At that time, the Gadkari of Shivneri Fort, Vijayrao Sidhoji Vishwasrao, was related to Shahaji Raja. Jijau made a vow to Shivai Devi, the abbot of the fort, 'If I have a son, I will name him after you'. In the year 1551, Shukla Naam Samvatsara, Uttarayana, in the month of Falgun, on the third day of Vadya, in the season of Shishir, on the constellation Hasta, on the auspicious day of Leo (on February 19, 1630), Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj was born at Shivneri Fort.

detailed.title: Mughals Rule
detailed.content: In 1632, Shivaji left the fort and in 1637, it was captured by the Mughals. In 1650, the Kolyas here rebelled against the Mughals, in which the Mughals were victorious. In 1673, Shivaji unsuccessfully tried to capture the fort by defeating the Shivneri fort's fort-holder Aziz Khan.

detailed.title: Shahu Maharaj
detailed.content: In 1678, the Junnar province was plundered and the Marathas tried to capture the fort. However, they failed. Later, 40 years later, in 1716, Shahu Maharaj brought the fort under Maratha rule and later it was transferred to the Peshwas.

detailed.title: East India Company
detailed.content: Dr. John Fryer of the East India Company visited the fort in 1773. He mentioned in his handbook that the fort had enough provisions to last a thousand families for seven years.

name: Pratapgad
historicalSignificance: The Fort of Triumph - Witness to Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj's Victory Over Afzal Khan.

history.summary: Built in 1656 under the orders of Shivaji Maharaj, Pratapgad Fort was a strategic military outpost and the site of the famous encounter with Afzal Khan.

detailed.title: Making of Pratapgad
detailed.content: In 1656, Shivaji Maharaj defeated Chandrarao Morya and captured 'Jawali'. In the valley of Jawli, at the mouth of Parghat and at the nose of Radtondi Ghat, 'Bhorpya Dongar' stood like a guardian. Maharaj ordered Moropant to build a fort on this Bhorpya mountain. Moropant, using his skills in fort building, built a lofty and impregnable fort in 1658; that is Pratapgad. Maharaj appointed Arjoji Yadav as the first fortmaster of Pratapgad.

detailed.title: Afzal Khan Encounter
detailed.content: In 1659, Afzal Khan marched on Swarajya with a huge army. Maharaj cleverly brought him to the valley of Jawli under Pratapgad. On 9 November 1659, at 2 pm, Shivaji killed Afzal Khan and wiped out his huge army with guerrilla warfare, ending this crisis that had befallen Swarajya. In 1661 AD, the Maharaja installed the shrine of Mahishasurmardini Bhavani Devi on the fort.

detailed.title: Strength
detailed.content: During the long period from 1659 to 1818, except for a short period in 1689, the enemy could not conquer this fort.

name: Harishchandragad
historicalSignificance: The Sentinel of the Sahyadris - A Fort Steeped in Ancient Glory and Natural Splendor.

history.summary: Harishchandragad is an ancient fort with caves and temples dating back to the 6th century, offering historical and natural experiences.

detailed.title: Location and Geography
detailed.content: Harishchandragad is a mountain located on the left side of Malshej Ghat, on the border of Thane, Pune, and Nagar districts. It is naturally protected by rugged and fierce mountains, making it an excellent example of how geography can impact a fort's history and structure.

detailed.title: Historical Background
detailed.content: The history of Harishchandragad is unique, with a mythological background dating back two to four thousand years. It is mentioned in the ancient Agni Purana and Matsya Purana. In 1747-48, the Marathas took control of the fort from the Mughals and appointed Krishnaji Shinde as the fort keeper.

detailed.title: Trekking and Scenic Views
detailed.content: Harishchandragad is considered a 'trekker's paradise' due to its breathtaking natural beauty. From the highest peak of the fort, Taramati, trekkers can enjoy panoramic views of surrounding areas such as Naneghat, Jivdhan, Ratangad, Katrabaichi Khind, Ajobacha Dongar, Kalsubai, Alang, Madan, Kulang, Bhairavgad, Hadsar, and Chavand.

detailed.content: In 1818, following the decline of Maratha power, Rajmachi Fort was eventually captured by the British, marking the end of its significance under Maratha rule.

name: Lohagad
historicalSignificance: The Iron Fort – A Symbol of Strength and Maratha Resilience.

history.summary: Built during the Satavahana period, Lohagad became a strategic fort during Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj's reign. Its unique 'Vinchu Kada' feature symbolizes the fort’s natural strength and historic significance.

detailed.title: Early Construction and Historical Background
detailed.content: Lohagad Fort is believed to have been constructed before the nearby Buddhist caves of Bhaje and Bedse, dating back over 2,000 years.

detailed.title: Under Adilshahi and Shivaji Maharaj's Control (1630–1657 AD)
detailed.content: In 1630, Lohagad came under the rule of the Adilshahi dynasty. However, in 1657, after conquering Kalyan and Bhiwandi, Shivaji Maharaj took control of the fort and incorporated it into his growing Maratha empire, securing the region's strategic defense.

detailed.title: Treaty of Purandar and Recapture (1665–1670 AD)
detailed.content: As part of the Treaty of Purandar in 1665, Lohagad was handed over to the Mughals, but on 13 May 1670, the Marathas, under the leadership of Shivaji Maharaj, recaptured the fort, reaffirming Maratha control.

detailed.title: Wealth Storage during Surat Loot
detailed.content: After the successful loot of Surat, Netaji Palkar stored the wealth in Lohagad, further underlining the fort's significance in the Maratha economy and defense strategies.

detailed.title: Shahu Maharaj’s Rule and Administration
detailed.content: In 1713, after the death of Sambhaji Maharaj, Shahu Maharaj transferred control of Lohagad to Kanhoji Angre, a trusted Maratha admiral. Later, in 1720, the fort came under the control of the Peshwas, marking another significant period in the fort's history.

detailed.title: British Capture and Control (1800–1818)
detailed.content: In 1803, the British captured Lohagad, temporarily taking control of the fort. However, it was later recaptured by Bajirao Peshwa. The fort remained a key site during this period of fluctuating power between the British and the Marathas.

name: Karnala
historicalSignificance: The Funnel of the Sahyadris – A Watchtower Fort with Rich Natural Beauty.

history.summary: Karnala Fort, dating back to the 12th century, served as a watchtower for several rulers, including the Yadavas and Marathas. It is now part of the Karnala Bird Sanctuary, blending history with nature.

detailed.title: Early Construction and Satavahana Period
detailed.content: The tanks found within Karnala Fort suggest its origins may trace back to the Satavahana period, though historical records place its significance during the Yadava period. This makes the fort an ancient site with strategic importance over many centuries.

detailed.title: Shivaji Maharaj’s Conquest (1657 AD)
detailed.content: In 1657, Shivaji Maharaj captured Karnala Fort, adding it to his expanding Maratha empire. The fort, strategically located along the trade route, provided a valuable military advantage, especially for controlling the Kalyan region.

detailed.title: Treaty of Purandar and Mughal Control (1665 AD)
detailed.content: In 1665, as part of the Treaty of Purandar, Karnala Fort was handed over to the Mughals. The fort was one of 23 forts that came under Mughal control after the treaty between Shivaji Maharaj and the Mughals.

detailed.title: Recapture by Marathas (1670 AD)
detailed.content: After the Treaty of Purandar, Shivaji Maharaj launched an attack and recaptured Karnala Fort in 1670, along with the entire Kalyan province, before the onset of the monsoon season. This act was part of his efforts to strengthen his kingdom and regain lost territories.

detailed.title: Mughal Control during Sambhaji Maharaj's Reign
detailed.content: During the reign of Sambhaji Maharaj, the fort was recaptured by the Mughals, continuing the back-and-forth control between the Marathas and Mughals over strategic locations.

historicalSignificance: The Lion's Fort – A Testament to Maratha Bravery and Sacrifice.

history.summary: Sinhagad, previously known as Kondhana, stands as a symbol of Maratha valor, especially for the heroic sacrifice of Tanaji Malusare during its recapture by Shivaji Maharaj.

detailed.title: Adilshahi Rule and Dadoji Konddev’s Appointment
detailed.content: Initially, Sinhagad Fort (originally known as Kondana Fort) was under the Adilshahi rule. Dadoji Konddev was appointed as Subhedar by the Bijapur rulers (Adilshahis). He played a key role in the administration of the fort and surrounding region.

detailed.title: Shivaji Maharaj’s Acquisition (1647–1649)
detailed.content: After the death of Dadoji Konddev in 1647, Shivaji Maharaj made efforts to bring Kondana Fort under his control. He bribed Siddi Ambar, the fort's owner, and successfully took control of the fort, establishing it as a military base for the Marathas. In 1649, Shivaji Maharaj returned the fort to the Adilshahis in exchange for the release of his father, Shahaji Maharaj.

detailed.title: Treaty of Purandar and Mughal Control (1665 AD)
detailed.content: As part of the Treaty of Purandar in 1665, Sinhgad Fort was handed over to the Mughals along with 22 other forts. Udebhan Rathod, a Rajput who had converted to Islam, was appointed as the fort’s commander on behalf of the Mughals.

detailed.title: Tanaji Malusare’s Sacrifice (1670 AD)
detailed.content: Sinhgad Fort is most famously associated with the sacrifice of Tanaji Malusare, one of Shivaji Maharaj’s most trusted commanders. In 1670, after Shivaji Maharaj escaped from Agra and began reclaiming the forts taken by the Mughals, Tanaji was entrusted with the task of recapturing Kondana. The historic battle, which took place on the night of 4th February 1670 (Magh Vadya Navami), saw Tanaji's courageous efforts to scale the fort walls with his 500 men. A fierce battle ensued with the Mughal Rajputs, and despite being outnumbered, Tanaji and his men fought valiantly. However, Tanaji Malusare fell in the battle, but his brother, Suryaji Malusare, took charge, rallied the remaining forces, and eventually captured the fort. Upon hearing the news of Tanaji’s death, Shivaji Maharaj famously remarked, 'One fort has been taken, but one fort has been lost.'

detailed.title: Naming of Sinhgad Fort
detailed.content: After Tanaji’s sacrifice, Shivaji Maharaj renamed the fort Sinhgad ('Lion’s Fort') in honor of his brave general. However, historical documents indicate that the name Sinhgad was already in use even before Tanaji's battle. For instance, Shivaji Maharaj himself mentioned Sinhgad in a letter dated 03/04/1663.

historicalTimeline.event: Sinhagad was established as a hill fort.
Reclaimed by Shivaji Maharaj after the valiant efforts of Tanaji Malusare.

name: Takmak
historicalSignificance: Takmak Fort – A Remote Stronghold with Historical Significance and Stunning Views.

history.summary: Takmak Fort, located in the Vasai region, served as a strategic military post during the Maratha and Portuguese rule. The fort offers panoramic views and remnants of ancient fortifications.

detailed.title: Construction and Early Control (12th Century)
detailed.content: Takmak Fort was constructed in the 12th century by King Bhimdev, the son of King Bimbdev. It was initially an important fort under local control before coming under the rule of the Sultan of Gujarat.

detailed.title: Shivaji Maharaj’s Conquest
detailed.content: Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj likely conquered Takmak Fort as part of his efforts to secure several forts, including Kohaj-Asheri. This fort became an integral part of his growing kingdom, strengthening the Maratha presence in the region.

detailed.title: Portuguese Control After Shivaji Maharaj's era
detailed.content: Takmak Fort came under Portuguese control, following their expansion in western India.

detailed.title: Chimaji Appa and the Vasai Campaign
detailed.content: Chimaji Appa, the brother of Baji Rao I, played a crucial role in the Vasai Campaign. As part of this campaign, the Marathas captured Takmak Fort from the Portuguese in 1732, further weakening Portuguese control in the region. However, the Treaty of Vasai signed between the Marathas and the Portuguese led to the return of the fort to the Portuguese.

detailed.title: Peshwa Control
detailed.content: On 8th April 1737, Pantaji Moreshwar captured Takmak Fort from the Portuguese. The Peshwas subsequently assigned 25 villages to the Begami of Takmak Gad. After this, the fort continued to serve as a Maratha stronghold, although its strategic importance began to decline.

name: Vasota
historicalSignificance: Vasota Fort – A Hidden Gem in the Sahyadri Range, Known for Its Scenic Trek and Maratha Legacy.

history.summary: Vasota Fort, also known as Vyaghragad, was used as a strategic stronghold by the Marathas due to its natural defenses and difficult terrain. It is surrounded by the Koyna Wildlife Sanctuary.

detailed.title: Antiquity and Early History
detailed.content: The origins of Vasota Fort are believed to trace back to the time of sage Vasishtha. According to legend, Agasti Rishi, a disciple of Vasishtha, crossed the Vindhya Mountains and found a southern route. He settled on the peak of the Koyna ridge in the Sahyadri mountain range, naming the mountain after his guru. Over time, local Kshatriyas constructed a bastion on this peak, turning it into a military post. The name Vasishtha gradually evolved into Vasota.

detailed.title: Shivaji’s Campaign (1660 AD)
detailed.content: After being trapped at Panhalgad following the assassination of Afzal Khan, Shivaji Maharaj sent a detachment from Maval to capture Vasota. On 6th June 1660, they successfully took control of the fort, marking an important addition to the Maratha Empire.

detailed.title: Captivity of English Prisoners (1661 AD)
detailed.content: During the Maratha-English confrontations, Faron and Samuel, two English prisoners, were held captive at Vasota Fort in 1661.

historicalTimeline.event: Vasota Fort becomes an important stronghold for the Marathas.
Vasota Fort is used to secure the surrounding areas of the Koyna River.

name: Durgadi
historicalSignificance: Durgadi Fort – A Historic coastal Fort Strategically Positioned Overlooking the Ulhas River.

history.summary: Durgadi Fort is believed to have been built during the time of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. It was a watchtower fort strategically located to oversee the trade routes of the Kalyan region.

detailed.title: Shivaji Maharaj’s Conquest and Construction (1654 AD)
detailed.content: On 24th October 1654, Shivaji Maharaj conquered Kalyan and Bhiwandi from Adil Shah. After this victory, Shivaji started constructing a fort near the Bhuikota of Kalyan, situated on the banks of a creek. During the construction, immense wealth was discovered while digging the foundation, which was seen as a blessing from Goddess Durga. As a result, the fort was named Durgadi.

detailed.title: Naval Development
detailed.content: Along with the fort, Shivaji Maharaj established a naval dockyard and began manufacturing warships to strengthen the Maratha naval forces. To assist in this effort, 340 Portuguese craftsmen were employed for their expertise in shipbuilding.

detailed.title: Mughal Conquest and Recapture (1682–1689 AD)
detailed.content: In 1682, Hasan Ali Khan, a Mughal Sardar, captured Kalyan. However, in the same period, Sambhaji Maharaj launched a counterattack and recaptured Kalyan. Later, in 1689, the Mughals again took control of Kalyan, marking a brief period of Mughal dominance over the region.

detailed.content: Although there is limited historical documentation about Korigad Fort, the caves on the fort suggest that it dates back to ancient times, indicating its long-standing significance.

name: Vijaydurg
historicalSignificance: Vijaydurg Fort – An Ancient coastal Fort with Strong Historical Roots and Stunning Views of the Arabian Sea.

history.summary: Vijaydurg, known for its strong coastal defenses, was built by the Marathas to protect the Konkan coastline from foreign invasions. The fort is situated on a hill overlooking the Arabian Sea.

detailed.title: Construction and Early Dynasties (1193–1664 AD)
detailed.content: Shilahar Raja Bhoj of Kolhapur built the fort between 1193 and 1206 AD. Over time, it came under the rule of the Yadav, Vijaynagar, Bahamani, and Adilshahi dynasties.

detailed.title: Conquest and Strengthening by Shivaji Maharaj (1664 AD)
detailed.content: Shivaji Maharaj captured the fort in 1664 AD and renamed it Vijaydurg. He fortified the fort by adding a triple wall and the Gomokhhi Darwaza, enhancing its strategic importance.

detailed.title: Sarkhel Kanhoji Angre's Naval Base
detailed.content: After Shivaji, the fort came under the control of Sarkhel Kanhoji Angre, the legendary Maratha naval commander. It served as the base of the Maratha fleet. In 1717 AD, the Marathas captured the English ship Sussex and docked it in Vijaydurg harbor, alarming the British.

detailed.title: Joint Attack and Capture by the British and Peshwas (1756 AD)
detailed.content: In 1756 AD, the British and Peshwas collaborated to confront Tulaji Angre. The British attacked from the sea, and the Peshwas attacked from the land, resulting in the destruction of the Maratha fleet. Vijaydurg Fort was captured and handed over to the Peshwas in exchange for Bankot Fort. Anandrao Dhulpa was appointed governor of Vijaydurg by the Peshwas.

name: Khanderi
historicalSignificance: Khanderi Fort – A coastal Fortress that Played a Key Role in Maratha Naval Defense.

history.summary: Khanderi Fort was constructed by the Marathas to defend the coastal regions of Konkan. The fort is situated on an island off the coast of Alibaug and has strong historical ties to the Maratha Empire's naval defense system.

detailed.title: Strategic Selection and Initial Construction (1672 AD)
detailed.content: Shivaji Maharaj identified the island of Khanderi as a critical location to monitor British trade routes to Mumbai and northern ports. Initial construction began in 1672 AD, but British resistance temporarily halted the effort.

detailed.title: Completion Under Maynak Bhandari (1679 AD)
detailed.content: In 1679 AD, under Maynak Bhandari's leadership, 150 Maratha soldiers were stationed at Khanderi to complete the fortification. The British opposed the effort by blockading supplies, but the Maratha navy, led by Daulat Khan, innovated by using shallow vessels to deliver supplies during low tides. Despite British resistance, the fort was completed, and the British signed a truce with the Marathas in 1680 AD.

detailed.title: Attacks and Defenses
detailed.content: On 8 March 1701, Siddi Yakut Khan attacked the fort but failed to capture it. In 1718 AD, the British launched another attack with a large fleet of warships. Mankoji Suryavanshi and 500 Maratha soldiers defended the fort for nearly a month, forcing the British to retreat.

history.summary: Underi Fort was built by the Marathas to defend the coastline from naval invasions. It served as a guard post and has remnants of old fortifications. It is situated on an island and offers a peaceful escape for nature lovers.

detailed.content: On 9th January 1680, Siddi began fortifying Underi Island. The Marathas launched their first attack on 27th January 1680, but it was unsuccessful.

detailed.content: On 28th January 1681, Naro Trimbak successfully captured the fort, renaming it Jaidurg.

name: Bassein
historicalSignificance: Bassein Fort – A Historic Portuguese Stronghold with Rich Architectural Heritage on the Arabian Sea Coast.

history.summary: Bassein Fort, also known as Vasai Fort, was constructed by the Portuguese in the 16th century. It became a significant naval and trading post. The fort is a blend of historical ruins and picturesque landscapes, with parts of it still in good condition.

detailed.title: Early History and Construction
detailed.content: 1414 AD: Sardar Bhandari Bhendale built Vasai Fort. 1530 AD: The fort was captured by the Sultan of Gujarat. 1534 AD: The Portuguese recognized the strategic importance of the fort and took control of it, spending ten years reconstructing and strengthening the fort. The fort is decagonal, with bastions at each corner and is 1 km in length and width. The ramparts are about 30 meters high and 5 meters wide, making it a formidable structure. Notable bastions include Bahri Buruz, Kalyan Buruz, Phateh Buruz, Kailas Buruz, and Darya Buruz. The fort has two entrances—one from the seaside and one from the landside, and there are secret passages. It is surrounded by swamps on three sides and the sea on one side, with water sources available inside the fort.

detailed.title: Maratha Attempts to Capture Vasai
detailed.content: 1739 AD: The fort became a focal point of Maratha efforts. Under the leadership of Bajirao Peshwa, Chimaji Appa was selected to capture the fort. He strategically planned to attack from the swamp side and broke through the rampart on the northern side. The Marathas faced difficulties with mines, resulting in a heavy skirmish. The battle, which started on 2nd May 1739, lasted two days, resulting in 800 Portuguese casualties. The Portuguese were eventually forced to surrender, with the Marathas allowing the women and children of the Portuguese to leave safely.

name: Ratangad
historicalSignificance: Ratangad Fort – A Majestic hill Fort Known for Its Unique 'Eye of the Needle' Rock Formation and Scenic Views.

history.summary: Ratangad Fort, also known as the 'Jewel Fort,' was an important military post during the Maratha Empire. The fort is famous for its 'Nedhe' (eye-shaped window) and offers stunning views of the surrounding Sahyadri range.

detailed.title: Early History and Construction
detailed.content: The origin of Torna Fort is not clearly documented, but the caves and sculptures found at the site suggest that it dates back to the Shaiva Panth period, indicating that it may have been built by the followers of Lord Shiva.

detailed.title: Maratha Control under Shivaji Maharaj
detailed.content: 1646 AD: Shivaji Maharaj captured Torna Fort and named it Prachandagad. He renovated and strengthened the fort, adding new structures and monuments. After his escape from Agra, he returned to Torna, where he carried out further renovations.

detailed.title: Mughal Control
detailed.content: After the assassination of Sambhaji Maharaj, the Mughals took control of the fort. Aurangzeb took possession of Torna Fort in 1704 AD and named it Futulgaib (meaning 'The Divine Victory'). This was the only fort that Aurangzeb captured through direct military action.

detailed.title: Maratha Regaining Control
detailed.content: However, within just four years, in 1708 AD, Sarnobat Nagoji Kokate was able to retake the fort for the Marathas. The fort remained in Maratha hands after the Treaty of Purandar, where Torna was retained by Shivaji Maharaj.

name: Torna
historicalSignificance: Torna Fort – One of the First Forts Captured by Shivaji Maharaj, Offering a Challenging Trek and Majestic Views.

detailed.content: Torna Fort holds great historical significance as it was the first fort captured by Shivaji Maharaj at the young age of 16. The fort served as an important military stronghold for the Marathas and played a key role in the expansion of the Maratha Empire.

detailed.content: The fort was constructed by Shivaji Maharaj after his victory over Chandrarao More. It was strategically important and served as a part of the larger network of forts managed by the Marathas, particularly in conjunction with Raigad Fort.

detailed.title: Treaty of Purandar
detailed.content: Under the Treaty of Purandar, both Raigad and Lingana remained under Maratha control, ensuring their strategic significance in the Maratha kingdom.

detailed.title: Temples and Worship
detailed.content: The fort was home to two deities, Shree Janani and Somjai, who were worshipped by the fort's caretakers and the people living in the region.

detailed.content: Jivdhan Fort is believed to have originated during the Satvaahan era, as indicated by the stone-carved entrances found on the fort. This suggests the fort's historical importance and its role in guarding the region.

detailed.title: Strategic Importance
detailed.content: The fort is strategically located, particularly overseeing the Naneghat, a famous pass used for trade and military movements. From Jivdhan, assistance could be sent swiftly to Naneghat, making it an essential guard post in the region.

detailed.title: Nizamshahi Control
detailed.content: Jivdhan Fort was initially under the control of the Bahmani Sultanate and later came under the rule of the Nizamshahi dynasty. Its importance continued to grow, particularly during the decline of the Nizamshahi dynasty.

name: Mahuli
historicalSignificance: Mahuli Fort – A Historical Hill Fort Known for Its Unique Pinnacles and Thrilling Rock Climbing Opportunities.

history.summary: Mahuli Fort, a protected monument, served as a strategic watchtower for Marathas during the reign of Shivaji Maharaj.

detailed.title: Unknown Origins
detailed.content: The exact creator of Mahuli Fort remains unknown. However, it is believed to have existed during the Nijamshahi period, which began with Malik Ahmed in 1485. The fort later became an important military post in the region.

detailed.title: Shahaji Raje's Involvement (1635-36)
detailed.content: When Shahaji Raje became the secretary to the Nijamshahi, the fort was embroiled in the power struggles of the region. During a period of political instability, Shahaji Raje, under increasing pressure from the Adilshahi and the Mughals, transferred himself, Jijabai, and Shivaji Maharaj to Mahuli for safety.

detailed.title: Shivaji Maharaj's Control (1658)
detailed.content: In 1658, Shivaji Maharaj successfully took control of Mahuli Fort from the Mughals. However, in 1661, the fort was handed back to the Mughals. Shivaji Maharaj regained the fort in 1661, and it remained under Maratha control for a while. However, under the Treaty of Purandar in 1665, the fort was once again lost to the Mughals.

detailed.title: Mughal Control & Fortification (1665-1670)
detailed.content: Under Mughal rule, Manohardas Gaud, a Mughal sardar, was appointed as the in-charge of Mahuli Fort. He carried out significant construction work to fortify and strengthen the fort's defenses. In February 1670, Shivaji Maharaj attempted to retake Mahuli Fort but failed after thousands of Marathas were killed in battle, a devastating blow to the Marathas.

detailed.title: Final Maratha Victory (1670)
detailed.content: On 16 June 1670, after several months of efforts, Moropant Pingle succeeded in capturing Mahuli Fort, along with Bhandargad and Palasgad, which became a part of Maratha Swarajya (the Maratha kingdom).

name: Kothaligad
historicalSignificance: Kothaligad Fort – A Picturesque Pinnacle Fort Known for Its Unique Funnel-Shaped Summit and Scenic Trails.

history.summary: Kothaligad Fort, also known as Peth Fort, served as a watchtower for Marathas and a place for refuge during conflicts.

detailed.title: Mughal Conquest (1684)
detailed.content: In November 1684, Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb ordered his warriors, Abdul Kadar and Ali Biradarkani, to capture forts belonging to Sambhaji Maharaj's empire. One of the primary objectives was to seize control of Kothaligad Fort, which held strategic importance in the Kokan region. Abdul Kadar understood the significance of this fort and devised a detailed plan for its capture. He sent spies to infiltrate the surrounding region and gain inside information. His plan involved sending 300 gunmen to the base of the fort in November 1684.

detailed.title: The Siege of Kothaligad
detailed.content: Initially, the Marathas defended the fort successfully, forcing the Mughals to retreat. However, some Mughals managed to reach the Magarkot Dwar (Magarkot Gate) and began shouting, 'open the door.' Mistakenly, the Marathas inside assumed that these men were their own soldiers coming for supplies, and they opened the gate. The Mughals quickly stormed the fort, and a battle ensued. With the help of Mankoji Pandhere, the Mughals were able to capture the fort.

name: Suvarnadurg
historicalSignificance: Suvarnadurg Fort – A Strategic Coastal Fortification Known as the 'Golden Fort' of the Arabian Sea.

history.summary: Suvarnadurg Fort, built as a maritime defense post, played a key role in safeguarding the Konkan coast.

detailed.title: Construction and Early History
detailed.content: Suvarnadurg Fort was originally built during the Shilahar dynasty. The fort's strategic location played a key role in its significance. In 1660, Shivaji Maharaj captured the fort after defeating Ali Adil Shah. Shivaji Maharaj subsequently rebuilt and strengthened the fort, enhancing its defensive capabilities. The fort is notable for its hidden entrance, a unique feature designed to protect the fort from surprise attacks.

detailed.title: Role During Rajaram Maharaj’s Reign
detailed.content: During the reign of Rajaram Maharaj, the fort played an important role in the Maratha naval defense. Kanhoji Angre, the famous Maratha naval commander, was tasked with dealing with the dishonesty of the fort's castellan. Under his leadership, the fort became an important asset in maintaining control over the region.

detailed.title: Rise of Tulaji Angre
detailed.content: After the death of Kanhoji Angre, his son Tulaji Angre took charge of Suvarnadurg, making it the seat of his power. Tulaji Angre had a significant influence on the Maratha navy. However, tensions arose between Tulaji Angre and the Peshwas. In the ensuing conflict, the Peshwas were supported by the British.

detailed.title: Bajirao Peshwa’s Attempt to Seek Refuge
detailed.content: In 1802, during the conflict between Bajirao Peshwa and Yashwantrao Holkar, Bajirao Peshwa sought refuge in Suvarnadurg Fort to escape the advancing forces of Holkar. However, he was eventually forced to flee to Vasai as he was pursued by Holkar's forces.

name: Bankot
historicalSignificance: Bankot Fort – A Scenic Coastal Fort Overlooking the Savitri River Estuary, Known for Its Historical Trade Importance.

history.summary: Bankot Fort served as a strategic trade and defense point for the Konkan coast, with roots tracing back to the Portuguese and Maratha rule.

detailed.title: Early References and Name Changes
detailed.content: The first reference to the fort is found in the works of the Greek traveler Pliny in the 1st century AD, where he refers to it as Mandargiri or Mandgor. There are no further records until 1548, when the Portuguese captured the fort from Adilshah. The fort's early history is not well-documented, but its strategic importance was evident.

detailed.title: Capture by Kanhoji Angre and Renaming
detailed.content: Later, Kanhoji Angre, the renowned Maratha naval commander, took control of the fort and renamed it Himmatgad. Under Angre's leadership, the fort became an important part of the Maratha naval defense system. It played a significant role in maintaining control over the coastline.

detailed.title: Peshwa-Angre Rivalry and British Involvement
detailed.content: During the period of rivalry between the Peshwas and Tulaji Angre, the Peshwas formed an alliance with the British to weaken Angre's power. As a result, the Peshwas and the British waged a war against the Angres. Commander James, leading the British forces, captured Himmatgad and renamed it Fort Victoria in honor of the British victory.

detailed.title: Decline and Handing Over to Peshwas
detailed.content: Despite its capture, Fort Victoria was found to be economically unviable to maintain. Due to its lack of strategic and economic value, the British eventually decided to hand the fort back to the Peshwas. The fort was then under Peshwa control, but its significance gradually diminished in the years that followed.

name: Panhala Fort
historicalSignificance: Panhala Fort – A Majestic Hill Fort with Strategic Importance and Strong Connections to Maratha History.

history.summary: Panhala Fort is one of the largest forts in the Deccan Plateau and was a key stronghold for the Maratha Empire under Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. It played a crucial role in the empire's military history.

detailed.title: Early History
detailed.content: The fort of Panhalgad was originally built during the reign of Bhoj Nrupsingh, the First Shilahar king. It was initially ruled by the Nag tribe, who were of a tribal caste, and it was known as Pannnagralya in those times.

detailed.title: Maratha Era
detailed.content: The Marathas gained control of Panhalgad after the assassination of Afzalkhan, taking advantage of the weakening of the Adilshahi dynasty. Shivaji Maharaj captured the fort in just 18 days on 28th November 1659, solidifying his power in the region. However, the fort was briefly recaptured by the Adilshahi forces, but the Marathas regained control soon after. On 2nd March 1660, Siddhi Johar, a commander of the Adilshah's army, laid siege to Panhalgad, leading to the famous escape of Shivaji Maharaj through the God Khind to reach Vishalgad, marking a historic moment in Maratha history.

detailed.title: Later Years
detailed.content: In 1673, Kondaji Farjand, a brave Maratha officer, managed to capture the fort again with just 60 soldiers. In 1710, Panhalgad became the capital of Kolhapur under Shivaji's successors, further establishing its significance in Maratha history.

detailed.title: Construction
detailed.content: Shivaji Maharaj, known for his strategic foresight, built Padmgad, along with Rajkot and Sarjekot, to safeguard the prominent fort of Sindhudurga. Padmgad was constructed on a rock situated between the Malvan seashore and Sindhudurga, serving as a protective barrier to prevent attacks via this route.

detailed.title: Strategic Importance
detailed.content: The rock on which Padmgad was built was skillfully carved to create a dockyard. This dockyard was used for the construction and repair of ships, reflecting Shivaji Maharaj’s focus on naval strength and maritime infrastructure.

detailed.title: Natural Phenomena
detailed.content: Prior to the Tsunami, it was possible to walk to Padmgad from the mainland during low tide, showcasing its accessibility and connection to the surrounding geography. However, the natural disaster altered the landscape, making such travel challenging today.

history.summary: Chawand, also known as Prasannagad, was originally under the Nizam Shahi dynasty and later became a strategic fort of the Marathas.

detailed.content: Malik Ahmed, the founder of the Nizam Dynasty, acquired Chavand Fort following the dissolution of the Bahmani Empire.
The fort served as a prison for Bahadurshah, the grandson of the seventh Nizamshah, Second Burhanshah. Bahadurshah, a nephew of the renowned Chandbibi, gained her support in his quest for the throne.
As part of a treaty with the Mughals, Shahajiraje, the father of Shivaji Maharaj, relinquished Chavand Fort to Mughal control.

detailed.title: Shivaji Maharaj
detailed.content: Shivaji Maharaj renamed the fort Prasannagad, reflecting its integration into the Maratha empire.

historicalTimeline.event: Built during the rule of the Nizam Shahi dynasty.
Captured by Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj and renamed Prasannagad.

keyPoints: Saptamatrika (The Seven Cisterns): Aligned water tanks with mythological names: Brahmi, Maheshwari, Kaumari, Vaishnavi, Varahi, Indrayani, and Chamunda. Temple partially buried in the earth near these cisterns.

Human-Made Caves: Located on the northern side of the fort, these caves are near the fortification's end. A secret passage is believed to exist beneath the caves. Offers a view of the river Kukdi from the south, originating at Kukdeshwar. The southeastern side lacks fortifications due to steep falls.

Temple of Goddess Chamunda: Situated on the topmost hillock of the fort. Likely brought by traders from Bengal, Bihar, or Mysore via the Naneghat route. Locally called 'Chavand,' giving the fort its name.

name: Ajoba Fort
historicalSignificance: Ajoba Fort - A Mythologically Significant Site Believed to Be Associated with the Ramayana.

history.summary: Ajoba Fort is not just a trekker's paradise but also a site of mythological importance, believed to be connected to the story of Lord Ram and Sita.

detailed.title: Mythological Significance
detailed.content: It is believed that Goddess Sita stayed here during her separation from Lord Ram, and sage Valmiki wrote the Ramayana in the vicinity.

detailed.title: Natural and Historical Aspects
detailed.content: The fort is surrounded by lush greenery and offers an adventurous trekking experience along with a glimpse into its past.

historicalTimeline.event: Associated with the Ramayana era as the site of Sita’s stay.
Utilized as a strategic lookout point.

keyPoints: Ashram and Hut: The ashram is a sacred spot, attracting visitors from across Maharashtra. A small hut nearby serves as accommodation for trekkers. A small water stream provides fresh water for visitors.
Carved Stones: Near the ashram, carved stones with idols depict a story, adding a cultural and historical element to the site.

Path to the Cave of Luv-Kush: The cave is accessible after crossing a rivulet and ascending the waterfall route for approximately 1.5 hours. Inside the cave are carved 'Padukas' (footprints) attributed to Luv and Kush, adding religious and mythological significance.
Cradle of Sitamai: Above the Luv-Kush cave is a precipice called the 'Cradle of Sitamai,' which presents a thrilling challenge for experienced trekkers.

name: Visapur Fort
historicalSignificance: A Hill Fort Known for Its Magnificent Architecture and Scenic Views.

history.summary: Visapur Fort, built during the early 18th century, is a prominent hill fort in the Sahyadri range, known for its vast plateau and historical significance.

detailed.title: Early History
detailed.content: Located in Nane Maval, this region became part of Nizamshahi after the dissolution of the Bahmani rule.

detailed.title: Mughal and Maratha Struggles
detailed.content: Under the Treaty of Mahuli, the forts were handed over to the Mughals by Shahajiraje. In the mid-17th century, Shivaji Maharaj regained control of these forts during his campaign, capturing most of the region by 1660. The Treaty of Purandar (1665) once again ceded the forts to the Mughals, although Aurangzeb later disregarded this treaty.

detailed.title: Mughal Invasions
detailed.content: In 1682, Shahbuddin, a Mughal commander, launched an assault on the region, killing 60 Marathas in anger. Despite this, the Marathas escaped to Visapur Fort and then to the nearby village of Kusapur, avoiding further casualties.

detailed.title: British Conquest
detailed.content: On 4th March 1818, Colonel Prother of the British forces captured Visapur Fort. The next day, Lohgad Fort also fell to the British.

historicalTimeline.event: Built under the leadership of Balaji Vishwanath.
Captured by the British forces.

keyPoints: Large plateau with remnants of old houses, water tanks, and bastions.
Panoramic views of Lohagad Fort, Pawna Lake, and surrounding valleys.
Monsoon waterfalls and lush greenery.

Camping sites near the fort base.

name: Prabalgad Fort
historicalSignificance: A Hill Fort Offering Breathtaking Views and Historical Importance.

history.summary: Prabalgad Fort, perched atop the Prabal Plateau, was originally built by the Bahmani Sultanate and later came under the rule of the Marathas.

detailed.title: Early History and Origin
detailed.content: The fort, initially known as Muranjan, was likely built to protect the prominent ports of Panvel and Kalyan. The presence of Buddhist caves on the hill suggests its origin during the Buddhist era. It became a military checkpost under the Shilahar and Yadav kings due to its strategic location.

detailed.title: Shahaji's Refuge
detailed.content: In 1636, amidst attacks by the Mughals and Adilshah of Bijapur, Shahaji, then a Nizam commander, sought refuge at Kondhana and Murumbdev hills. After failed attempts to gain help from the Siddi of Janjira and the Portuguese of Chaul, Shahaji, along with his wife Jijabai and younger son, Shivaji Maharaj, took refuge in Prabalgad Fort.

detailed.title: Maratha Conquest
detailed.content: In 1656, after defeating Chandrarao More in the Jawali region, Abaji Mahadeo, a commander under Shivaji Maharaj, captured the region extending from Kalyan and Bhiwandi to Cheul and Rayri, including Muranjan Fort. The fort was renamed Prabalgad under Maratha rule.

detailed.title: Treaty of Purandar and Mughal Control
detailed.content: In 1665, as part of the Treaty of Purandar, Prabalgad was among the 23 forts handed over to the Mughals. Mirzaraje Jaisingh, a Rajput commander of the Mughals, appointed Kesharsingh Hada as the in-charge of the fort.

detailed.title: Maratha Retaliation
detailed.content: When the treaty was broken, the Marathas attacked Prabalgad, resulting in Kesharsingh's death. Before the attack, the Rajput ladies on the fort committed johar (self-immolation) to avoid capture. Kesharsingh’s mother and two sons, found hiding in the trees, were handed over unharmed to the Mughals in Deoolgaon village.

historicalTimeline.event: Built by the Bahmani Sultanate.
Captured by Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj.

keyPoints: Vast Plateau: The summit is a sprawling plateau blanketed with dense forest, offering a tranquil and secluded atmosphere.
Temple of Lord Ganesh: A small temple dedicated to Lord Ganesh stands at the summit, adding a spiritual element to the fort's significance.
Water Tanks: There are 2-3 water tanks on the fort, providing a vital water source for visitors and trekkers. A water tank is also located along the steps descending to the Kalavantin pinnacle.
Remnants of Structures: The fort has ruins of ancient structures that hint at its historical and architectural heritage.

Views and Surrounding Features: Several points of Matheran can be spotted from the top, offering breathtaking panoramic views. The Kalavantin Pinnacle, located adjacent to the fort, is accessible via rock-cut steps descending into a cleft between the two landmarks.
localAccommodation: Lodging options in Panvel and Karjat.
Camping options at the fort base.

howToReach.trekRoute: From Thakurwadi, take the trail leading to Prabalgad through dense forested paths.

faqs.answer: Yes, the trek is moderate in difficulty and suitable for beginners with a reasonable level of fitness.

name: Irshalgad
historicalSignificance: A Pinnacle with a Unique Structure Offering Stunning Views.

history.summary: Irshalgad is not a fort in the traditional sense but a pinnacle, historically used as a watchtower by various rulers.

detailed.title: Misnomer and Nature
detailed.content: The name Irshaalgad is a misnomer, as Irshal is not a fort but a pinnacle. Due to its nature, it has minimal historical significance and is rarely mentioned in historical records.

detailed.title: Maratha Rule
detailed.content: In May 1666, Shivaji Maharaj captured the entire Kalyan and Bhiwandi region, extending up to Rairi. It is likely that Irshal came under Maratha rule during this period. Irshal is situated near Prabalgad, which adds to its strategic location.

historicalTimeline.event: Served as a watchtower for regional rulers.
Came under the control of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj.

keyPoints: Water Tanks: There is a water tank along the route from the Irshal plateau to the peak, which provides drinking water for trekkers.
Needle Hole: A prominent feature on the route is the needle hole near the top, which can be reached via a simple rock-climbing route. This is a key landmark on the way to the pinnacle summit.

Cave and Water Tank: After passing the needle hole, you’ll encounter a water tank on the left and a cave on the right. The water tank provides potable water, making it a good resting spot during the trek.

Rock Climbing: To reach the top of Irshal Pinnacle, rock climbing is necessary. Artificial climbing equipment is required for this challenging ascent to the summit, which is quite steep and technical.
Panoramic Views: From the top of the pinnacle, trekkers can enjoy panoramic views of several neighboring forts: Prabalgad, Matheran, Chanderi, Malanggad, Karnala, and Manikgad.
localAccommodation: Stay options in Karjat or Panvel.
Camping options available near the base village.

howToReach.trekRoute: The trek starts from Chowk village and includes a moderate climb through forested paths and rocky sections.

faqs.answer: Yes, the trek is relatively easy and suitable for families with children above 10 years.

faqs.answer: There are a few water cisterns near the base, but carrying your own water is recommended.

name: Arnala Fort
historicalSignificance: A Coastal Fort Known for its Strategic Location in the Arabian Sea.

history.summary: Built by the Portuguese and later controlled by the Marathas, Arnala Fort has served as a key maritime stronghold.

detailed.title: Foundation by Sultan Mahmood Begda
detailed.content: Sultan Mahmood Begda of Gujarat built Arnala Fort in 1516 to secure the coastline.

detailed.title: Portuguese Control
detailed.content: In 1530, the Portuguese captured the fort and began building new structures on it, taking control for over 200 years.

detailed.title: Maratha Control
detailed.content: The Marathas eventually took over the fort after the Portuguese rule. Bajirao-I reconstructed the fort, rebuilding it in a style similar to the Portuguese architecture.

detailed.title: British Capture
detailed.content: In 1817, the British captured Arnala Fort, similar to their conquest of other forts in the region, marking the end of Maratha control.

historicalTimeline.event: Constructed by the Portuguese as a strategic fort.
Captured by the Marathas under Chimaji Appa.

keyPoints: Fort Shape: The fort is approximately rectangular in shape, with continuous and strong ramparts standing about 10 meters tall, ensuring strong protection.
Bastions: The bastions of the fort are in good condition and are strategically positioned, with two big bastions at both sides of the main entrance.

Main Entrance: The main entrance is on the north side, with impressive carvings of an elephant and a tiger on both sides, symbolizing the strength of the ruler. A lithograph at the entrance indicates that Bajirao Peshwa reconstructed the fort.
Temples: Inside the fort, there are temples dedicated to 'Tryambakeshwar' and 'Bhavani Mata'. Additionally, a 'Kalikamata' temple is located along the way to the main entrance.
Octagonal Lake: In front of the 'Tryambakeshwar Mahadev' temple is a well-built octagonal lake, adding to the fort's beauty and significance.
Water Wells: The fort has wells providing drinking water for visitors, ensuring the fort's self-sufficiency.
Small Bastion: From the beach, a small bastion is visible to the left of the main fort, accessible via a small entrance.

Fort Exploration: It takes about 30 to 45 minutes to explore the fort. The strong ramparts offer a great vantage point for viewing the surrounding area, with a projection above the main entrance providing a complete view of the fort.
localAccommodation: Stay options in Virar or Vasai.
Simple homestays available near the base village.

howToReach.trekRoute: A short boat ride from Arnala Beach to the island, followed by a 5-minute walk to the fort.

faqs.answer: While the fort is accessible, boat rides may be disrupted due to heavy rain or high tides.

name: Vairatgad
historicalSignificance: An Ancient Fort Offering Scenic Views and Historical Insights.

history.summary: A historic fort used as a watchtower and refuge by local rulers, later under the control of the Marathas.

detailed.title: Foundation by King Bhoj
detailed.content: King Bhoj of the Shilahar dynasty built Vairatgad Fort in the 11th century.

detailed.title: Military Station during Shivaji Maharaj's Period
detailed.content: During Shivaji Maharaj's period, the fort was primarily used as a military station to strengthen Maratha defenses.

detailed.title: Maratha Control
detailed.content: Shivaji Maharaj conquered the Wai region, which included Vairatgad and Pandavgad, incorporating them into his kingdom.

detailed.title: British Capture
detailed.content: In 1818, the British captured Vairatgad Fort, bringing it under their control.

historicalTimeline.event: Constructed during the Satavahana period.
Controlled by the Maratha Empire.

keyPoints: Small Summit: The top of the fort is relatively small and is home to remnants of old buildings, offering a glimpse into the fort's past.
Dilapidated Bastion: The bastion at the entrance is in a dilapidated condition, marking the fort's age and exposure to the elements.
Cisterns: To the left of the main gate, on the lower side of the cliff, there are 5-6 cisterns that once provided water to the fort.
Small Cave: A small cave can be found to the right of the main entrance, adding to the fort's intriguing features.
Hanuman Temple: At the top, there is a Hanuman temple, with a statue of Hanuman located both inside and outside the temple.
Plinths: Several plinths can be seen around the temple and surrounding area, hinting at the historical significance of the site.
Good Condition Rampart: The rampart remains in good condition, offering strong defensive features despite the fort's age.
Village Access: The fort has a gap in the cliff opposite the main entrance, through which one can climb down to the nearby village of Mhasava.
Indecipherable Writings: A hillock near the gap features a stone with indecipherable writings, hinting at the fort's deep history and potential future discoveries.
Fort Exploration Time: It takes approximately one hour to explore the fort, making it a relatively quick but rewarding visit.

detailed.title: British Period

Fort came under British control.

Lotus Carving: Inside the doorway, there is a carved lotus flower in stone, symbolizing artistic craftsmanship.
Raised Platform: Opposite the entrance, a raised platform is situated, behind which lies a doorway leading to the seaside.

name: Khubladha Fort
historicalSignificance: A hill fort known for its rugged terrain and strategic importance during the Maratha reign.

history.summary: Khubladha Fort served as a strategic lookout post and played a crucial role in the Maratha Empire.

detailed.title: Strategic Location
detailed.content: The fort was constructed on a natural elevation along the Thal coast, providing a strategic advantage.

detailed.title: Support Role
detailed.content: In 1659, Khubladha served as an offshore base for men and materials during the construction of Khanderi Fort. It played a pivotal role in safeguarding the mainland from invasions by the British and the Siddis.

detailed.title: Conquest and Retake
detailed.content: In 1749, the Siddis conquered Khubladha Fort. However, Manaji Angre recaptured it in 1750 during a battle that resulted in the death of 200 Siddi soldiers.

detailed.title: Abandonment
detailed.content: Due to increasing vulnerability to attacks, the fort was eventually abandoned, and operations shifted to the Colaba Fort in Alibaug.

historicalTimeline.event: Fort established as a strategic outpost.
Used extensively during the Maratha conflicts.

keyPoints: Panoramic views of the Western Ghats.
Rich biodiversity in the surrounding forests.
Remains of ancient fortifications.

name: Hadsar Fort
historicalSignificance: A fort known for its iconic architecture and role in the Maratha history.

history.summary: Hadsar Fort has been a key defensive structure during various regimes, including the Marathas and the Mughals.

detailed.title: Historical Origins:
detailed.content: Fort Hadsar, also known as Parvatgad, was built during the Satvahana period and was densely inhabited during that era.

detailed.title: Strategic Location:
detailed.content: Situated on the outskirts of Ahmednagar, the fort was strategically placed to control the trade route through Naneghat.

detailed.title: Role in Historical Treaties:
detailed.content: Historical records indicate that Hadsar was one of the forts involved in the 1637 treaty between Shahaji Raje and the Mughals.

detailed.title: British Conquest and Demolition:
detailed.content: In 1818, British forces captured Junnar and the surrounding forts, including Hadsar. During their attack and subsequent rule, key features of the fort were demolished, leaving it in ruins.

historicalTimeline.event: Established during the Satavahana dynasty.
Fort reinforced under the Maratha rule.

keyPoints: Medieval Architecture: The entrance gates of Hadsar Fort showcase medieval architecture with twin doors, a tunnel-like entranceway, rock-carved steps, and 'Gomukhi' construction.
Path Division: Beyond the main entrance, the path splits into two—one leading to the hillock top and the other to the second gate.
Water Cistern: A water cistern with potable water is located immediately after the second gate, serving as a vital resource for visitors.
Rock-Carved Stores: Three large stores carved into the cliff are found near the cistern, though they are not suitable for accommodation.
Ganesh Carvings: The rock face features images of Lord Ganesh, adding religious significance to the site.

Mahadeo Temple and Pond: A Mahadeo temple with a huge Nandi and a six-cornered hall containing idols of Lord Ganesh, Garuda, and Hanuman is situated near a large pond that fills completely during the monsoon.
Central Well Construction: A stone-walled well-like structure is located at the center of the pond, demonstrating ancient water management.
Strong Bastion: Adjacent to the temple is a robust bastion, highlighting the fort's defensive design.
Sand-Filled Cistern: Descending from the bastion wall reveals a cistern now filled with sand and soil.
Survey Cave: A carved-out cave in the rock was used for surveying purposes, offering insight into historical practices.
Panoramic Views: The fort provides splendid views of the Manikdoh dam and the surrounding areas, including Chavand, Naneghat, Shivneri, Bhairavgad, and Jeevdhan.

busesAvailable: State transport buses from Pune to Junnar.
howToReach.trekRoute: The trek starts from the base village of Hadsar and involves ascending a rugged trail with steep sections.

faqs.question: Is the trek safe for children?
faqs.answer: The trek is moderately challenging and not recommended for children below 10 years.

faqs.question: Are there water sources available at the fort?
faqs.answer: Yes, there are ancient water cisterns, but it is advised to carry your own drinking water.

name: Jaigad Fort
historicalSignificance: A coastal fort strategically located to guard the Jaigad Creek and the surrounding areas.

history.summary: Jaigad Fort was an important fort during the Maratha Empire, protecting trade routes and serving as a strategic maritime base.

detailed.title: Construction
detailed.content: Built during the 16th century by the Bijapur Sultanate and later captured by the Marathas.

detailed.title: Role in Maratha Empire
detailed.content: Jaigad Fort served as a significant naval base for the Maratha fleet under Kanhoji Angre.

detailed.title: Current State
detailed.content: The fort is well-preserved and offers stunning views of the Arabian Sea and the Jaigad Creek.

historicalTimeline.event: Built by the Bijapur Sultanate.
Captured by the Marathas under Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj's rule.

keyPoints: Strategic Location: Jaigad Fort is situated on a small plateau, with a smaller version of the fort extending towards the creek.
Defensive Trench: A dry trench separates the main fort from the plateau, creating a barrier that makes direct attacks on the fortification wall difficult.
Concealed Entrance: The main entrance is obscured by bastions, preventing direct assaults and enhancing the fort's defenses.
British Usage: During British rule, the bastions were repurposed as offices, with narrow windows used for administrative purposes, diminishing their original grandeur.
Lotus Carvings: The entrance door features carvings of two lotus flowers on either side, showcasing the fort's artistic elements.
Ruined Sculpture: A partially ruined sculpture in the center of the entrance remains unidentifiable due to its condition.
Porches and Storage: After entering the fort, two porches and a large room resembling an ammunition storage warehouse can be found.
Fortification Stairs: Stairs are built along the fortified wall, providing access to various levels of the fort.
Ruined Building: A three-story building once stood near the entrance, though only two stories remain today.
Rainwater Tanks: Behind the ruined building are two large tanks constructed to collect rainwater, essential for sustaining the fort's occupants.
Lord Ganesh Temple: A temple dedicated to Lord Ganesh is located near the water tanks, adding spiritual significance to the fort.
Ruined Mansion: In front of the temple is a mansion now in ruins, with arches on the right side completely devastated and the left side still intact.
Year-Round Wells: Two wells behind the structures retain water throughout the year, serving as a reliable water source.

busesAvailable: State transport buses from Ratnagiri to Jaigad.
howToReach.trekRoute: Minimal trekking required as the fort is easily accessible from the main road.

faqs.answer: Yes, the lighthouse is accessible and offers amazing views.

name: Pandavgad Fort
historicalSignificance: Pandavgad Fort served as a stronghold for the Maratha Empire and offers historical ruins with natural beauty.

history.summary: Pandavgad Fort is an ancient hill fort, believed to have connections with the Pandavas from the Mahabharata, and was later a part of the Maratha Empire.

detailed.title: Construction and Early Rule
detailed.content: Built during the reign of Shilahar King Bhoj-II (as per a copper plate inscription from 1191-1192). Initially under the rule of the Adilshahi dynasty.

detailed.title: Maratha Conquest
detailed.content: On 7th October 1673, the Marathas captured the fort, integrating it into Swarajya under Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj's leadership.

detailed.title: Aurangzeb's Occupation
detailed.content: In 1701, Aurangzeb seized the fort during his Deccan campaign.

detailed.title: Reclaiming the Fort
detailed.content: Later, Chhatrapati Shahu Maharaj reclaimed the fort for the Marathas.

detailed.title: British Capture:
detailed.content: In 1818, the British took control of the fort during their conquest of India.

historicalTimeline.event: Constructed and associated with the Pandavas.
Captured and fortified by the Marathas.

keyPoints: Lord Bhairoba Temple: Located on the first plateau, this temple houses remnants of ancient statues, adding a spiritual and historical dimension to the fort.
Main Entrance Ruins: The ruins of the main entrance can be reached after a 15-minute walk and ascending rock-hewn steps to another plateau ('Machi').
Cisterns on Machi: A couple of cisterns are located on the 'Machi', providing water sources for visitors.
Northern Tanks and Bungalow: On the northern side of the fort, two tanks and a Parsee’s Bungalow can be seen, showcasing the diversity of structures within the fort.
Cisterns on the Way to Balekilla: Six cisterns, including one larger one, and the indistinct remains of a seventh cistern, are found on the path to the citadel ('Balekilla').
Citadel Entrance and Bastions: The entrance and bastions of the citadel are well-preserved, reflecting the fort's architectural strength.
Ramparts and Sculptures: The 25 ft high ramparts feature a beautifully carved statue of Lord Hanuman on the left and a temple of Goddess Pandjai on the right.
Grinding Wheels: Three grinding wheels, used for preparing a mixture of limestone, jaggery, and lead, are present, with two in good condition.
Dried Lake and Old Constructions: A dried lake and remnants of old constructions near the temple add to the fort's historical intrigue.

detailed.content: The Portuguese captain Soj began the construction of Revdanda Fort in 1528. Prior to this, in 1516, the Portuguese had established a factory at Revdanda, known as “Chowkoni Buruj” or the square-shaped bastion. The walls of the factory were completed between 1521 and 1524.

detailed.title: Maratha Attack
detailed.content: On the night of July 22, 1683, the Marathas attempted to attack Revdanda, besieging the fort, but had to withdraw when the Portuguese launched an attack on Fonda.

detailed.title: Treaty and Transfer
detailed.content: According to the treaty on November 25, 1740, the Portuguese handed over Revdanda and Korlai forts to the Marathas and took control of villages on Sashti Island.

name: Tung Fort
historicalSignificance: Tung Fort, also known as Kathingad, is a hill fort strategically located for defense and surveillance during the Maratha rule.

history.summary: Built by the Adil Shahi dynasty and later captured by the Marathas, Tung Fort played a crucial role in the Maratha Empire's defense strategy.

detailed.title: Historical Significance:
detailed.content: Tung Fort and Tikona Fort were not as historically significant as some other forts in the region but played a role in the larger context of the Maratha Empire. In 1657, both forts became a part of Swarajya under Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, along with other forts situated in the Maval region.

detailed.title: Protection by Netaji Palkar:
detailed.content: In 1660, Netaji Palkar was appointed to protect the Maval region, which included Tung and Tikona Forts.

detailed.title: Jaysingh's Invasion (1665):
detailed.content: In 1665, Jaysingh invaded the region. His forces, including Dilerkhan, attacked and destroyed the villages around Tung and Tikona, but they were unable to capture the forts themselves.

detailed.title: Treaty of Purandar (1665):
detailed.content: Following the Treaty of Purandar (signed on 12th June 1665), the forts were handed over to the Mughal forces. Kubadkhan and Halalkhan, along with other Mughal officers, took control of the forts on 18th June 1665.

name: Sajjangad Fort
historicalSignificance: Sajjangad Fort, known as the 'Fort of Good People,' is the final resting place of the saint Samarth Ramdas Swami, spiritual guide of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj.

history.summary: Originally known as Parali Fort, it was renamed Sajjangad after being associated with Samarth Ramdas Swami. The fort became a spiritual hub during the Maratha era.

detailed.title: Saint Ashwalayan's Residency
detailed.content: The fort is also known as Ashwalayan Gad, named after Saint Ashwalayan, who is believed to have resided on this hill in ancient times. Over time, it became known as Ashwalgad.

detailed.title: Creation by King Bhoj
detailed.content: The fort was constructed by King Bhoj from the Shilahar dynasty in the 11th century. The village at the base of the fort is called Parali, leading to the fort also being referred to as the Fort of Parali.

detailed.title: Mention in Bahamani Dynasty
detailed.content: The fort is mentioned during the reign of the 4th Bahamani king, Mahommad Shah (1358-1375). Later, it came under the control of Adilshah, who took a portion of the Bahamani state.

detailed.title: Phajal Khan's Mention (1632):
detailed.content: In 1632, Phajal Khan is mentioned as being in charge of the fort.

detailed.title: Conquered by Shivaji Maharaj (1673)
detailed.content: On 2nd April 1673, Shivaji Maharaj conquered the fort from Adilshah.

detailed.title: Saint Ramdas' Residence and Name Change
detailed.content: At the request of Shivaji Maharaj, Saint Samarth Ramdas made the fort his permanent residence. The fort was renamed Sajjangad in honor of Ramdas' stay.

detailed.title: Sambhaji Maharaj's Involvement
detailed.content: After Shivaji Maharaj's coronation, Sambhaji Maharaj was sent to Sajjangad on 3rd November 1678. However, Sambhaji fled from Sajjangad on 3rd December 1678 and joined Dilerkhan.

detailed.title: Legacy of Samarth Ramdas
detailed.content: The fort is revered as the place where Samarth Ramdas Swami lived and spread his teachings.

detailed.title: After Shivaji Maharaj's Death (1682)
detailed.content: After the death of Shivaji Maharaj on 18th January 1682, the idol of Shriram was placed on the fort. Ramdas Swami also passed away on 22nd January 1682. Despite transferring all rights of the fort to Divakar Gosavi, the administration was handled by Bhanji and Ramji Gosavi, leading to conflicts between them. Sambhaji Maharaj wrote to Jijoji Katkar, the Killedar of Sajjangad, to resolve the disputes and ensure the orders of the elders were followed.

Captured and renamed by Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj.

name: Vishalgad
historicalSignificance: Vishalgad Fort, also known as 'Khelna' in earlier times, is a historically significant fort in Maharashtra that served as a key Maratha stronghold. It is known for its strategic importance and association with Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj.
distance: 7 km trek from the base village

history.summary: Vishalgad Fort played a pivotal role during the Maratha Empire. It was captured by Shivaji Maharaj in 1659 and renamed Vishalgad, meaning 'Grand Fort'.

detailed.title: Construction and Early History:
detailed.content: King Bhoj II shifted his capital from Kolhapur to Panhala around 1190 CE and built several forts, including Kishagila (later renamed Vishalgad) to protect key trade routes. The fort was initially under the rule of the Yadavas before falling to the Bahamanis.

detailed.title: Bahamani Sultanate and the Siege:
detailed.content: In 1453 CE, Malik Utujar, a commander of the Bahamani Sultanate, attempted to capture Vishalgad. The Shirke family led him into a dense forest, where the Muslim soldiers became exhausted. The Shirke and Mores launched a surprise attack, leading to the defeat of Malik Utujar and his entire army. This event was detailed by historian Ferista.

detailed.title: Bahamani Sultanate's Rule:
detailed.content: In 1469 CE, Malik Rehan was sent to capture the fort. He failed six times but ultimately succeeded after nine months of hardship. A dargah was later built in his memory on the fort, and the battle descriptions are inscribed there.

detailed.title: Maratha Control:
detailed.content: On 28th November 1659, Shivaji Maharaj captured Panhala and also took Khelna Fort, renaming it Vishalgad. During a siege on Panhala in March 1660, Shivaji Maharaj broke the siege of Vishalgad and sought refuge there. He strengthened the fort, spending 5000 hone currency for its fortification.

detailed.title: Sambhaji Maharaj's Era:
detailed.content: Sambhaji Maharaj added several new fortifications to Vishalgad. In 1686, during the Shirke rebellion, Sambhaji Maharaj took refuge in Vishalgad after being defeated by the Shirke. In 1689, Sambhaji Maharaj was captured and executed by the Mughals.

detailed.title: Rajaram Maharaj and the Maratha Capital:
detailed.content: Fort Vishalgad became a center for Maratha activities during Rajaram Maharaj's reign. Amatya Ramchandrapant made it his main headquarters, granting it the status of a capital. After Rajaram Maharaj's death in 1701, his wife Ambikabai performed suttee on the fort’s pyre.

detailed.title: Mughal Conquest:
detailed.content: In 1701, Aurangzeb laid siege to Vishalgad. After six months of resistance led by Parshuram Pantpratinidhi, the fort was handed over to the Mughals on 6th June 1702, in exchange for 2 lakh rupees. Aurangzeb renamed the fort Sarvarlana. His army suffered great losses during their march to Panhala, as described by Mughal historians.

detailed.title: Maratha Recapture:
detailed.content: Tararani recaptured Vishalgad in 1707 CE. The fort passed into the hands of the Karaveer Marathas and was later controlled by the Pantpratinidhi.

detailed.title: British Occupation:
detailed.content: In 1844, the British destroyed the fort's structures after capturing it.

name: Bhudargad Fort

history.summary: Bhudargad Fort was built as a watchtower and defense post and was later incorporated into the Maratha Empire under Shivaji Maharaj.

detailed.title: Maratha Conquest and Renovation:
detailed.content: Captured by the Marathas in 1667. Shivaji Maharaj renovated the fort, transforming it into a significant military post.

detailed.title: Shifting Control:
detailed.content: Adilshah recaptured the fort after its renovation by Shivaji Maharaj. The fort was retaken by the Marathas in 1672. Rajaram Maharaj stayed on the fort while returning from Gingee, emphasizing its importance in the Maratha empire.

detailed.title: Later Events:
detailed.content: Late 18th century: Captured by Parshurambhau Patwardhan. After about a decade, the Chatrapati of Karveer regained control of the fort. In 1844, during the Kolhapur mutiny, the fort's militia actively participated in the rebellion.

detailed.title: Defense and British Attack:
detailed.content: Babaji Ayrekar, the commanding officer, led the defense of the fort with the support of Subhana Nikam and his 300 soldiers. The British bombarded the fort, specifically targeting the main entrance, to seize control.

name: Devgiri
historicalSignificance: Devgiri Fort, also known as Daulatabad Fort, is one of the most remarkable forts in India, renowned for its ingenious defensive mechanisms and historical importance during the Yadava and Mughal eras.

history.summary: Constructed by the Yadava dynasty in the 12th century, Devgiri Fort has seen rulers like the Khiljis, Tughlaqs, Bahmanis, and the Mughals. Its strategic location and advanced defense systems made it a prized possession for many empires.

detailed.title: Architectural Description:
detailed.content: According to the Sabhasad Bakhar, the fort is described as huge in size but less in height.

detailed.title: Yadava Period
detailed.content: Built in the 12th century by King Bhillama V of the Yadava dynasty, it served as their capital.

detailed.title: Tughlaq Rule
detailed.content: Sultan Muhammad bin Tughlaq moved his capital from Delhi to Devgiri and renamed it Daulatabad.

detailed.title: Mughal Period

Amberkot Features: Amberkot, built by Malik Amber, surrounds Daulatabad town and has seven entrances named after nearby villages, such as Lasur.
Main Entrance Gate: The main gate features intact wooden doors with iron spikes and porches for guards.
Amberkot Moat: A moat surrounds Amberkot, crossed by a small bridge, with an internal structure worth exploring.

Jain Temples: The fort premises have Jain temples, a Deepmaal, and two plinths near the main entrance arch.
Hatti Talav: A massive water cistern near the second entrance measures 38x38x66 meters and stores 10,000 cubic meters of water.
Bharatmata Temple: This ancient Yadava-era temple, dedicated to Mother India, features intact pillars and a statue of Bharatmata.
Chand Minar: A 100-meter tower near Bharatmata temple, constructed in Irani style, commemorates Sultan Ahmed Shah's victory over Gujarat.
Kalakot Features: Kalakot includes Dindi Darwaja, Chini Mahal (prison), and Nizamshahi Palace with Buddhist caves at its rear.
Mendha Tof: A 23-foot cannon on a circular bastion, named 'Killa Shikan,' is designed to rotate in all directions.
Fort Moat: The moat, carved from the mountain base, features two bridges and steep, scraped walls to deter enemies.
Bhoolbhulaiya (Maze): A long tunnel with traps like boiling oil, chili smoke, and escape illusions to entrap invaders.

Bijali Darwaja: A door near Bardari leading to a big bastion with sacred footprints of Janardan Swami and potable water tank.
